title: Before 1 January 2018, will Turkey, Montenegro, Albania, Serbia, or Macedonia announce that it is suspending its participation in EU membership negotiations or withdrawing from the EU accession process?
preds: I doubt anything will happen in the next week.
all of this countrys will join the eu

These countries stand no chance to become EU members, yet they persist in this futile activity. Most EU hopefuls might not be ready to join before 2050, study finds A new study looking into the practical, legal and technical aspects of further EU expansion has concluded that only one country, the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, could meet the criteria for joining the bloc before 2023. Serbia, currently touted as the frontrunner together with the tiny coastal republic of Montenegro, would only manage to fully comply with EU law in the mid-2030s, and the same goes for Turkey, according to the Forecasting Candidate Status study, written by Professor Tina Freyburg of the University of St Gallen and Tobias Böhmelt from the University of Essex. Further enlargement of the EU during the 2014-2019 mandate of Jean-Claude Juncker’s Commission has been ruled out but the question of who might join the bloc next remains an interesting debate, even though there is little real appetite for bloc’s further expansion. The list of countries still vying for EU membership includes official candidates Albania, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia, and Turkey, and EU hopefuls Bosnia-Herzegovina and Kosovo. The study has considered how likely it is that five of those candidate countries would join the EU before 2050, based on previous accession benchmarks used during the 2004 big-bang enlargement. EU accession is only possible when candidate countries meet a comprehensive list of criteria and when they have implemented EU law, known as the acquis, into their own national legislation. This includes everything from judicial reform to transport and energy policy. The study said Macedonia is the only country likely to meet the benchmarks before 2023, while Serbia and Turkey would only manage to fully comply with EU law in the mid-2030s.
https://www.euractiv.com/section/enlargement/news/most-eu-hopefuls-might-not-be-ready-to-join-before-2050-study-finds/

Considering German media coverage, I see a minor likelihood that Turkey might announce (considering) suspending the participation, while I don't expect that any of the countries will make the call to withdraw from the accession process.
(no change) Erdogan in a PBS Newshour interview didn't really answer this question.
Turkey may want to apply pressure around German elections.

A. Merkel's statement on Turkey's EU membership may have been more than 50% short term political necessity.
Other EU members not supportive of her position.
http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2017/09/08/534495/Turkey-EU-children-game
Merkel is pushing for Turkey to be refused admittance. They are protesting this but does it count if it's not voluntary? according to clarification, no.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-turkey-merkel/in-shift-merkel-backs-end-to-eu-turkey-membership-talks-idUSKCN1BE15B?il=0 This is the sort of thing that might prompt Erdogan to jump before he's officially thrown overboard.   More likely the plug will not be formally pulled, but Turkey's candidacy will be permitted to languish to death.  Still, it's undoubtedly better for domestic political consumption if he indignantly withdraws candidacy once it becomes clear that nothing is going to happen.  However, if he doesn't do this fairly soon, he probably won't.

A leap into the realm of overconfidence, or do I have good reasons here? Base rate of announcements of suspension of EU membership negotiations initiated by the country that is petitioning to join? None that I can find.  Last year, the EU voted to suspend negotiations with Turkey, yet Turkey seems quite pleased to give the EU the middle finger by continuing its quest to join, at least on paper. It's too good a bargaining chip for Ergodan to give up. Plus, there  isn't much time left before the forecast horizon, no meetings scheduled between the EU and the membership negotiators of the nations at issue here, and Ergodan is too busy running purges, jailing reporters and dissidents, flattening Kurdish towns, and embroiling Turkey in conflicts in Syria and Iraq to waste time on the EU issue. I will continue to monitor the situation via the daily newsletters I receive from Foreign Policy, <fp@foreignpolicy.com> just in case something big were to change. CHAMPS KNOW checklist: Yes: Comparison classes.  Provide relevant classes and calculate base rates.
Yes: Hunt for info. Share the evidence that helps inform your prediction.
N/A Adjust. Explain the reason for updating your prediction.
N/A Models. Explain any application of mathematical or statistical models.
N/A Post-mortem. Interpret past failures and successes; draw implications for the future.
Yes: Select effort. Describe the optimal level of effort.
Yes: Know the power-players. Describe individuals with influence and how will they use it.
Yes: Norms & protocols. Describe laws, rules, scheduled meetings, etc., that matter.
Yes: Other perspectives. Describe bottom-up processes (protest, culture, market forces, technology, etc.) that may play a role.
No: Wildcards. Explain the sources and magnitude of uncertainty.

Despite Turkey being the most likely country to suspend its participation in EU membership negotiations, clinging to the talks with the EU representatives gives Erdogan another tool put pressure onto the EU - this is very much in line with his foreign policy. It seems unlikely that Turkey will join the EU but it won't stop being engaged with it either. As for the other states - even less likely to suspend talks. The EU is enjoying record highs of approval among European EU and non-EU countries thesed days.

It seems that Turkey likes to keep its option open . Although it appears that its progress toward EU membership is halted it seems to be reluctant to say so. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-turkey-idUSKCN1AX0RG
Maybe Turkey is taking the same approach that it has to the Akkuyu nuclear power plant and Russia; one day Turkey and Russia are friends and the power plant is "go", the next days Turkey and Russia are enemies and power plant is "stop", a day later they are friends again and it "go" once more.  So maybe Turkey thinks that if it holds on the EU will have a change of heart and will decide it does want an unreformed Turkey as a member.
Going down to Zero. Turkey is the only probable contender to suspend or withdraw, black swans apart, but @rene explains why this is unlikely in the short term.

Good analysis. Conclusion: "The de jure abandonment of Turkey’s EU ambition, no matter how unlikely an accession outcome is at this point, would rob Erdogan of an extremely useful political propaganda tool. At the same time, were the EU Commission and member states to actually end Turkey’s candidacy, it would mean not only admitting the failure of soft power and conditionality on a grand scale but also playing into Erdogan’s hand and solidifying his increasingly undemocratic grasp on power within Turkey. Thus, the European Parliament’s resolution—while it makes for good headlines and allows the EU to claim it is standing up for democracy in Turkey—in reality is little more than fodder for Erdogan’s domestic political game and a fig leaf for the EU." From: https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/turkey/2017-08-02/turkey-and-eus-diplomatic-stalemate?cid=%3Fcid%3Dsoc-twitter-eu_turkey_diplomatic_stalemate_paywall_free-080217 (article is not paywalled)

Dropping because I think if Turkey was going to announce it was withdrawing it would have by now. I think it is more likely that Turkey will be kicked off the process after it reinstates the death penalty.

(up 3) I wonder if the tension between Turkey and Germany would not lead to some kind of disapproving declaration from the European Commission, which in turn could prompt Turkey to officially withdraw from the effectively moribund accession process. So far the Turks had held back from such a step, but there are political costs for Erdogan in taking hits with only a verbal response. Still an outside chance, though.

Although the European Parliament wants to suspend Turkey's application its not their place to do so. They would need to get the European Commission to do it. However to produce a "Yes" answer requires Turkey to suspend its application. Its possible if the EC suspended Turkey's application Turkey could do as @Raahul_Kumar says and quit. But the EC is probably going to just keep the Turkish application frozen. (They need Turkey to stop refugees crossing to Europe) Erdogan is reported to have said that he is not bothered what the EU says, but he also said "we will continue being sincere with the EU for a little more time". I have no idea what that means, but it does not sound as if he is planning to suspend Turkey's application.

EU parliament calls for Turkey accession talks to be suspended
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-eu-parliament-idUSKBN19R194 I assume Erdogan will want to quit. No, you can't fire me, I quit.

ALDE MEP, Alexander Lambsdorff (FDP, Germany), shadow rapporteur on Turkey, said the European Union must re-think its relations with the Turkish government:  “The Progress report of the European Parliament clearly states that the accession talks with Turkey should be suspended. Turkey has been moving towards an autocratic style of government since the failed coup attempt and no longer fulfils the Copenhagen criteria. Member States and the European Commission should follow the example of Parliament and take bold steps. Instead of clinging to a failed process, we need to work on a new agenda with a focus on energy, foreign policy, civil society dialogue, trade and visa liberalisation.” http://alde.eu/en/news/957-respect-of-human-rights-and-the-rule-of-law-must-be-at-the-core-of-the-new-eu-turkey-agenda/ Turkey's EU dream is over, for now, top official says

Turkey would be the most likely to officially withdraw or suspend its application. Although its application is frozen for whatever reason Turkey seems to be reluctant to actually make the reality official.

The hot exchanges between Turkey and the EU seem to have halted. Erdogan has not yet announced the reintroduction of the death penalty, which would almost immediately lead to a halt (if not more) of the negotiations. On the contrary: he is seeking support from France to deal with the Quatar problem. The other countries: Macedonia has just renewed it's bid to join EU and Nato, the new prime minister of Serbia is pro-EU, Montenegro has joined NATO and is getting pressure from Russia.

Turkey and EU are certainly having a bad time in their relationship, but verbally closing the door closes  a variety of strategic possibilities for the future. Same door for the others referenced in this question.

Turkey is dangerous for the EU because it has become unstable with recent elections, and membership would benefit them hugely.  Albania and Macedonia being accepted into the EU would be like winning the lottery.  Acceptance into the EU has a huge upside to most Eastern European countries.  The best example of EU vs no EU is Cyprus and the economies of each side.

COMMENT:  This is the scenario I worry about:  whether or not it will occur, and how GJO Admins will look upon it.

I believe the clash of the values of Erdogan and other conservative Turkish politicians' vs those of liberal European legislators and executive leaders will continue to deteriorate relations. Many individuals of each of these opposing groups seems to be unable to help themselves to be conciliatory or pragmatic when it comes to their own values having to accommodate those of others. The same could be said of many differing peoples and nations but the gap between conservative Turkish and liberal European values is too wide to bridge or reverse in my opinion.
Down 50% to be under the consensus and following @Nik and others: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/500566

(Down 10). Erdogan sounds more conciliatory. Looks like the focus in the Turkey-EU relations would be on pragmatic cooperation on issues like the refugees and the customs union (see http://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-eu-minister-idUSKBN1871XA). Also it seems that on both side there are both agitators that push for radical outcomes and pragmatists who don't want to rock the boat too much. The death penalty issue could provide clues - if Erdogan pushes it to the back burner, a formal break with the EU would be less likely.

I'm lowering my forecast based on the reasons given by @matuschoma below: "First thing I notice the question asks whether any of the countries mentioned above suspends or withdraws so it is up to those countries alone NOT EU to pull the trigger. Am I correct?  "Secondly most of the comments found here have political character and lack substance- mon€y flows (later I will come back to this). 
But even from the politics perspective everyone has many more reasons to continue with negotiations than not. EU wants to have influence over the balkans and SEE as well as Turkey so why would they let something like coruptions in Macedonia and elsewhere stop them?!  At the same token in all of these countries from Serbia to Turkey there are too many people- constituents who crave for EU that their respective political representatives cant afford to ignore them.  "And now the money. Look at the export/ import data between these countries and EU especialy Germany. And FDI. You will find there is too much capital invested and too much trade flowing to stop these negotiations.  Thus I find current predictions too pesimistic i.e. still way too high." However, I am worried about how GJO Admins will resolve this question if Turkey crosses one of the EU's "red lines".  Will the GJO Admins consider that Turkey pulled the trigger by taking an action they knew would result in suspension of the process, or will the Admins decide that it was the EU which pulled the trigger.

http://www.ansamed.info/ansamed/en/news/sections/politics/2017/05/09/turkey-desires-to-continue-process-of-eu-accession-erdog_c6a290d6-617b-477f-b019-7939715b091c.html 09 MAY, 19:02  Turkey wants to continue the process of accession to the European Union, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan wrote in a message for Europe Day on Tuesday. . . . The Turkish president then cited the March 2016 accord on migrants as "the most concrete and recent example" of this desire.

https://europeanwesternbalkans.com/2017/04/10/ewb-interview-genoveva-ruiz-calavera-eu-accession-process-is-strategic-investment-in-peace/ Genoveva Ruiz Calavera is responsible for managing bilateral relations between the EU and Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia, Kosovo, Montenegro and Serbia, guiding and monitoring their progress towards the EU . . . . "How would you assess the current situation in Macedonia? Macedonia is not moving forward on its path towards EU. What should be done to move it forward? "Genoveva Ruiz Calavera: I am deeply worried about the latest developments in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Commissioner Hahn and High Representative / Vice-President Mogherini, as well as Members of the European Parliament Eduard Kukan, Knut Fleckenstein and Ivo Vajgl, have been very clear – all leaders of the country, including the President, must respect the outcome of the recent elections. . . . We expect . . . the new government, to implement all parts of the Pržino agreement and the Urgent Reform Priorities in order to bring the country back onto its EU path.  "As a candidate country, Serbia has committed to progressively aligning, by the time of accession, with the EU Common Foreign and Security Policy. Alignment rate goes beyond numbers but it does mean increasingly putting EU interests first. "Serbia is making steady progress towards its strategic goal of EU membership. Its EU perspective is firm and real and we work closely with Serbia, as partners and friends, in addressing common challenges– migration, economic inequality, threats of terrorism – and preserving peace and stability in the region. In this context, Serbia’s active participation in EU civil and military crisis management missions, including common security and defence policy operations, is very appreciated. "There is no political blockage in Serbia’s EU accession negotiations. We are on good track. We have already opened eight chapters and closed two of them. Member States started discussion on another one mid-January. Serbia has also been invited to prepare the ground for several other chapters and is carefully assessing its positions before transmitting them to the EU. All those steps have serious implications and take time. This is normal. What is key, however, is the quality of the reforms behind the opening and closing of the chapters: delivering rule of law and a thriving market economy for the benefit of Serbian citizens. Serbia and Kosovo have committed to the normalisation of their relations and this is part of the negotiations framework with Serbia. I am confident that further progress will be made this year, for Serbia and Kosovo’s better future.
. . . 
"At the moment, we can see that the accession negotiations with Serbia are gathering pace: there are actually eight chapters currently opened (including six since July) and two provisionally closed. More are in the pipeline and I am confident that further progress will be made in the coming months. "EWB: What are the key challenges of Montenegro on its road to the EU? Is it administrative capacity or corruption or something else? "GRC: Montenegro is a country with a clear European perspective. The current political situation is complex with the opposition choosing to boycott the Parliament.  Inclusive dialogue is crucial for Montenegro for the modernisation of the country and we expect all Montenegrin politicians to engage in constructive discussions. Montenegro is the frontrunner of the EU integration process with legislative and institutional reforms well underway but there are of course certain challenges. More concrete progress is needed in many areas, most notably on the rule of law where a credible track record needs to be created. I look forward to Montenegro taking ownership of the reforms and moving forward on the EU integration path. @matuschoma:  Since you live in this area, I'm wondering what your thoughts are on this question.  Most forecasters seem to think that there's little chance of Montenegro, Albania, Serbia, or Macedonia announcing suspension of participation in EU membership negotiations or withdrawing from the EU accession process; do you agree?
Total guess, based on Turkey's political dynamics.
Turkey is the most likely candidate. It does not serve Erdogan to continue into EU's orbit, especially with the momentum he has in seizing power. Any cooperation with EU would erode his power.

1.Although the European Parliament's (EP) Turkey rapporteur Kati Piri and European Commissioner for European Neighborhood Policy Enlargement Negotiations Johannes Hahn called on the EU to immediately suspend Turkey's accession, Hungary and Greece think it "would be irrational" to end to the negotiations. Thus, despite the obstacles, Turkey's accession negotiations will likely continue as the EU member states must reach a unanimous vote to block negotiations.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union 2.President Recep Tayyip Erdogan says Turkey will decide in a referendum whether to continue pursuing membership in the European Union.

Don't know whether Erdoğan is playing shenanigans or what: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-eu-idUSKBN17Y0U0
With the referendum won, Erdogan is much less likely to play that card, which is only useful as a threat.

Turkey: the EU won't do it - they want good relations to keep refugees at bay. Erdogan has said he wanted discussions in Parliament and/or a referendum. But that was when relations with a number of EU countries were rapidly souring before the referendum on presidential powers. Now, if Erdogan wants to be a president of all Turks, he will be well advised not to bring this up. Turks are divided half/half on the pro/anti-European axis, and further discussions can only aggravate divisions further. That said, Erdogan might still do it - to crush the pro-European parties, if he calls parliamentary elections, etc. Hence the 10% None of the other countries has any incentive to suspend the talks.

"Germany rejects calls for EU to end Turkey accession talks Germany said it's against breaking off accession talks between Brussels and Ankara. The country's sentiment echoed EU foreign affairs head Mogherini's desire for Turkey to join the EU, if it can meet all the conditions. After a meeting of EU foreign ministers and the Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu in Valletta on Friday, the EU's respresentiative for foreign affairs, Federica Mogherini, said she still wants Turkey to join the bloc and that negotiations between Ankara and Brussels have not been suspended. She did, however, add that there is mounting concern over President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's growing crackdown on civil liberties. In remarks to reporters at the meeting's conclusion, Mogherini welcomed Turkey's desire to join the EU but said that "a level of clarification" was needed from Ankara." http://www.dw.com/en/germany-rejects-calls-for-eu-to-end-turkey-accession-talks/a-38629155
Germany opposes EU ending Turkey's accession, so it's unlikely EU will do it.  It sounds like Erdogan may  hold a referendum on it.
Erdogan of Turkey will withdraw from negotiations.

The accession process for Turkey seems to be the most likely to collapse; Austria, France and Greece have been lukewarm or opposed to Turkey's accession from the start and are clamoring more loudly that it should be suspended.  But if the action is taken by the EU side,  I'm afraid this question won't resolve  as "yes", even though GJO has stated that it doesn't want questions to resolve on technicalities. Erdogan seems to want to end Turkey's accession process.  EU criticism galls him.  Previously, it had sounded to me like Erdogan intended to use the referendum to support a decision by him to withdraw, but since the referendum he has said he'd take the issue to Parliament, which muddies the water considerably.  Beyond that, Erdogan has suggested that he'd hold a referendum on the issue if Parliament doesn't stop the process, which then would lengthen the process and make the 1/1/18 deadline an issue. Bottomline for me is that I think that so long as Erdogan is in power in Turkey this is more of a question of "when?" than "if?", and of "by whom?"  I'm adjusting my forecast downward to neutralize my previously high forecast.

Thanks @Dsarin for the clarification! That creates a problem. If the EU informs Turkey that it (the EU) has dropped Turkey from the accession process then presumably its too late for Turkey to announce it is suspending its participation. That would be like announcing your resignation after you have been fired, i.e. totally meaningless legally. 
The EU was holding back on ending Turkey's application in order to leave a route for Turkey if it changed its ways. This has clearly not got anywhere but Erdogan was threatening to hold a referendum this year on stopping Turkey's application to join the EU.  Maybe that will go ahead after the latest rows over the vote to change the constitution and threat to reintroduce capital punishment.

As progress has been halted on Turkey's membership and the European Parliament voted six months ago to suspend negotiations, and as Turkey has since moved further away from the EU's ideas of democracy and political freedom, it surely must be just a case of when the European Commission officially suspends the membership negotiations.

I'm moving up twelve points because Erdogan won the referendum and now seems to be looking for a way to end negotiations, I'll be keeping and eye on whether he calls a referendum on the death penalty.
The EU may beat Erdogan to declaring the end of the process for Turkey.
Up 10% until we see what Erdogan plans.

Unlike at least one other president we could name, Erdogan alppears to have a coherent long-range view of what he wants to do and how he intends to do it.  However, he has not yet shared it with me, so holding this number until the pattern gets clearer.
Turkey will eventually officially declare its withdrawal. Question is when. Erdogan will want to keep that card as long as possible, rather than actually playing it.

http://www.euronews.com/2017/04/10/turkey-is-no-longer-an-eu-candidate-mep-says "German liberal MEP Graf Lambsdorff. . . .said: “In law Turkey is still a candidate, in fact, it is not. Nobody believes in Brussels or in Ankara for that matter that Turkey will eventually join the European Union. . . . “Nobody in Europe, at least very few people, let’s put it that way, had the real intention, honest commitment to Turkey’s accession, . . .  France had always large majorities against Turkish accession, in Germany 80 percent of the people are opposed. Belgium, Netherlands, Luxembourg, Austria much the same. There is no democratic support for Turkey’s accession. And so we as Europeans have also been dishonest with our Turkish friends by telling them they can join eventually. But at the end of the day everybody knew that there was no majority inside for something like that.” The European Parliament recently voted to temporarily freeze accession talks with Turkey.But member states have been accused of remaining silent.
Mr Lambsdorff said: “Unfortunately the member states are too timid, too fearful but in the long run they are not rational in saying: ‘Well we should keep things as they are.’ The world around us is changing rapidly and it is time for the member states to change their position as well.”
. . .
Mr Lambsdorff said: “We should all realize that Turkey has imprisoned more journalists than either China or Iran. And that tells us a lot about the state of the freedom of speech in that country.  The arrests of people who are said to be related to the attempted coup – 47.000 over the past few months. All of this is not compatible with our standards for the rule of law. So in fact Turkey has already given up on looking towards Europe, for its standards, its values and its policies.”

http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2017/04/09/517409/Turkey-Erdogan-EU-referendum-crazy Erdogan  is saying Ankara will reconsider its bid for membership in the European Union (EU) after holding the plebiscite. Erdogan said " . . . referring to Germany and the Netherlands that have prevented Turkish ministers from campaigning on their soils for a “Yes” vote in the April 16 referendum.  “Europe will pay for what they have done. God willing, the question of the European Union will again be on the table after April 16,”  Erdogan also reiterated that after the next week’s plebiscite he would revive the capital punishment “without hesitation” – if it was passed by parliament – a move that would automatically terminate the EU membership bid. "Last month, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker warned that the measure was a “red line” in Ankara’s stalled bid. "The process has been mired in problems, and only 16 chapters of the 35-chapter accession procedure have been opened for Ankara so far. In November last year, the European Parliament suspended the accession talks with Ankara over concerns regarding human rights and the rule of law following the July 15 coup attempt against Erdogan, which Ankara claims was organized by US-based cleric Fethullah Gulen. In January, Turkey called on the EU to resume the negotiations.
Turkey Gov. mainly will use this card to pass the legislation & amendment

So everyone's upping their forecast because of Erdogan's announcement of a EU referendum. Well luckily my forecast was already higher 😊  Erdogan's announcement may play out in various ways. For example, his announcement of a EU referendum may give him a higher acceptance of his new powers in April -- or not. Even if Erdogan does not receive his new powers, he might still hold the referendum, to annoy the EU. Mostly, Erdogan's announcement increases the probability that the EU may want to cancel Turkey's EU membership negotiations before such a referendum in Turkey. Brussels would need to avoid the risk of a new humiliation I think. And that would count as 'No' in this GJO question!

This is politics, and politics can be wildly irrational and/or responsive to a narrow, short-sighted agenda. This question encompasses 5 countries: that ups the odds of a positive outcome. That said, perhaps my forecast is a bit high. The status quo (continuation of pursuit of accession) is generally the most likely outcome in any situation.

http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/governments-anti-eu-rhetoric-affects-serbian-citizens-02-07-2017 "Pro-EU opinion in Serbia is in decline, survey suggest.  According to a survey conducted [in December] by Serbia’s European Integration Office and published on February 6, if a referendum was held on Serbian membership of the EU, only 47 per cent would be in favour, 29 per cent would be against, 15 per cent would not vote, and 9 per cent would not know what to answer. . . . the latest results confirm a decline in support for Serbia’s EU accession in the last five years. Since June 2014, it has constantly been below 50 per cent. [Maja Bobic from the European Movement in Serbia] said . . .  anti-EU speech is being crudely used to mobilize voters but is damaging people’s view of the EU and their understanding of Serbia’s rights and responsibilities - damage that would be difficult to repair. . . .[and she] noted that anti-EU rhetoric is now present in all EU member states.  “Very often the EU serves as a culprit for national elites to avoid all internal problems and assume responsibility [for them]. So it's a trend that is becoming increasingly common,” Bobic concluded.

Turkey alone can make this question resolve as a YES: 1. Member of European Parliament want a temporary freeze on EU accession talks with Turkey. In a resolution voted on Thursday (Press release dated 24-11-2016 - 12:40), they say Turkey should nonetheless remain “anchored” to the EU. They also pledge to review their position when the "disproportionate repressive measures" under the state of emergency in Turkey are lifted. See Press release http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/news-room/20161117IPR51549/freeze-eu-accession-talks-with-turkey-until-it-halts-repression-urge-meps 2. Article 5 of the Negotiating Framework for Turkey, stipulates that " in the case of a serious and persistent breach in Turkey of the principles of liberty, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and the rule of law on which the Union is founded, the Commission will, on its own initiative or on the request of one third of the Member States, recommend the suspension of negotiations and propose the conditions for eventual resumption". 3.  Breaches of the principles of liberty, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms ... 
      A.  Acute human rights issues include in particular the status of Kurds in Turkey. The Kurdish–Turkish conflict has caused numerous human rights violations over the years. There is an ongoing debate in the country on the right to life, torture, freedom of expression as well as freedoms of religion, assembly and association.
     B.  Turkey's human rights record has long continued to attract scrutiny, both internally and externally. According to the Foreign Ministry, Turkey was sentenced to    33 million euros in 567 different cases between 1990—when Turkey effectively allowed individual applications to the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR)—and 2006 ***  The list of Turkey violations in the past is very long ***

4. The re-introduction of the capital punishment by the Turkish government would lead to a formal suspension of the accession process, say MEPs, pointing out that "the unequivocal rejection of the death penalty is an essential element of the Union acquis."
     A.   The death penalty has not been implemented in Turkey since 1984. Turkey abolished the sentence for peace time offences in 2002 and for all offences in 2004. The sentence was replaced by aggravated life imprisonment (ağırlaştırılmış müebbet hapis cezası). According to Article 9 of Law 5275 on the Execution of Sentences these prisoners are held in individual cells in high security prisons and are allowed to exercise in a neighbouring yard one hour per day. *** Erdogan has publicly stated his intention to reinstate the Capital Punishment:  "'I am convinced that parliament will approve it, and when it comes back to me, I will ratify it,' says President Erdogan in a speech in Ankara" http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/turkey-death-penalty-erdogan-reintroduce-debate-consider-turkish-parliament-a7386591.html
____________________________

1  The European Commission presented a positive evaluation overall of the progress made by the enlargement countries in 2016, noting that enlargement policy continues to deliver results and reforms are advancing in most countries. However, there are two notable exceptions to this trend: the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Turkey. 2. The last report on Turkey’s possible integration with the European Union is the harshest that has ever been written. The previous report, which was much milder compared to this one, was not accepted by Turkey. Turkish officials said they would return the report without reading it, and relations between Turkey and the EU have become much tenser since last year. 3  Bosnia and Herzegovina’s Progress Report is striking precisely for what it does not contain. The year saw the most direct and overt attack on the country’s peace, stability, and constitutional order since the adoption of the Dayton Peace Accords: the result of the September 25 referendum held in the Republika Srpska (RS) despite a decision by the Constitutional Court to suspend it. Despite this, the report mentions the event only once; “[the RS] Government organised…a referendum, ignoring the Bosnia and Herzegovina Constitutional Court decision to suspend the referendum until it decides on its constitutionality.” The omission is not accidental and reflects instead a profound disconnect between Brussels’ rhetoric and reality in the country. 4.  n the political sphere, the European Commission commended Serbia’s intensive legislative activity during the period ‘outside’ of elections, noting that the parliament’s work was suspended in March due to an early parliamentary contest in April. What it does not mention, however, is that Serbia’s new government was eventually formed only in August. The ‘useful’ period during which Serbian authorities were not engaged in electoral or post-electoral haggling seems therefore rather slim. 5.  This year’s progress report points out, more than ever, the paradoxes that characterise Kosovo’s relations with the EU: the country made significant progress towards EU membership via a Stabilisation and Association Agreement, while dealing with political turmoil and the dysfunctionality of its parliament for a good portion of 2016. 6.  The 2016 report on Montenegro was published in the interim between the parliamentary elections on 16 October and the approval of the new government led by the new Prime Minister Duško Marković in the country’s Parliament on 28 November. Presenting the Enlargement Package in Brussels on 9 November, Commissioner Hahn underlined that the steps made by the countries in the region confirm the salience of EU enlargement policy. 7.  This progress report was one of the most positive to date for Albania. The Commission for the first time recommended the opening of accession negotiations with Albania, with a conditional start date based on the implementation of a justice reform and in particular, the re-evaluation of judges and prosecutors, known as the ‘vetting law’.
____________________________

Turkey has to be the most likely contender here. Erdogan has expressed the willingness to do so, and there is scope (particualrly if the death penalty is reintroduced, as has been discussed), for the EU to suspend arrangements - which could serve as a trigger for Turkey to itslef suspend participation or withdraw. Against: this would be unprecedented.  And Turkey has been hanging on for such a long time in negotiations without them ever looking realizable in the short term. Counterargument: political situation in Turkey, post-attempted coup, and amid frequent large-scale terrorism, is more unstable than it has been for a long time. Brexit in particular also means that the EU itself is in a new position, of having an established member seek to leave. (That the UK has been a prime promoter of Turkish membership mayu also feed into this.) The other countries are overall unlikely to provoke a positive resolution of this question (numerous contentious issues notwithstanding.)
Erdogan consolidating power, plus I think rightward shift continues in Europe, so why give up sovereignty to a failing union?
